title: Ketan Patel - FINAL DRAFT

fields.name: Ketan Patel
fields.known_for: Co-founder and CEO of Greater Pacific Capital; founder and chair of the Force for Good Initiative; lead of a UNCTAD-hosted Future Capital working group on the future of finance
fields.alma_mater: London School of Economics; City University Business School (MBA)
fields.organization: Greater Pacific Capital; Force for Good Initiative

lead:
'''Ketan Patel''' (born February 1962) is a British investor, strategist and author.<ref name="R186" /> He is the chief executive and co-founder of the private equity firm ''Greater Pacific Capital'' (GPC) and the founder and chairman of the Force for Good Initiative, which publishes research on capital allocation, technology and sustainable development.<ref name="R147" /><ref name="R187" /><ref name="R188" /><ref name="R180" />

Patel was a managing director at Goldman Sachs, where he founded and led the bank's Strategic Group.<ref name="R220" /><ref name="R58" /><ref name="R211" /><ref name="R212" /> In 2003, ''The Globe and Mail'' referred to him as Goldman Sachs' “chief futurologist”.<ref name="R220" /> He previously served as a partner at KPMG, leading its European strategy consultancy and serving on the firm's board and European strategy team.<ref name="R220" /><ref name="R58" /><ref name="R62" /><ref name="R212" />

Patel participated in the UN-hosted Future Capital initiative and led its finance working group on the future of finance in support of the 2030 Agenda.<ref name="R195" /><ref name="R196" /> He is a trustee and executive director of the World Academy of Art and Science and serves on the advisory board of the UN Business and Human Security Initiative at the London School of Economics and Political Science.<ref name="R176" /><ref name="R193" />

Patel is the author of ''The Master Strategist'' (2005).<ref name="R216" /><ref name="R181" /> He has published on system-level transitions in geopolitics, technology and development in outlets including ''Frontiers'' journals, ''Cadmus'' and Reuters.<ref name="R174" /><ref name="R197" /><ref name="R161" /><ref name="R188" /><ref name="R189" /> In 2023, he told ''The Sydney Morning Herald'' that “This will be India’s century” and discussed India’s digital identity and payments infrastructure as a driver of financial inclusion and productivity gains.<ref name="R221" />

''The Master Strategist'' has been reviewed in ''Business Standard'' and ''IMFO'' and carried an endorsement quotation attributed to Nelson Mandela.<ref name="R210" /><ref name="R185" /><ref name="R218" />

sections.heading: Early life and education
sections.wikitext: Patel was born in February 1962 and grew up in London.<ref name="R186" /><ref name="R220" /> He graduated with a BSc in Economics from the London School of Economics and completed an MBA at City University Business School.<ref name="R220" /><ref name="R58" /><ref name="R62" /> He is an associate chartered management accountant (ACMA) and holds a postgraduate degree in neuroscience from King's College London.<ref name="R62" />

sections.heading: Career
sections.wikitext:
===Hewlett-Packard and KPMG===
Patel began his career at Hewlett-Packard before joining KPMG.<ref name="R207" /> At KPMG he led business-transformation strategy and headed the firm's European strategy consultancy.<ref name="R220" /><ref name="R58" /><ref name="R62" /><ref name="R207" /> He later became a partner and served on the firm's board and European strategy team.<ref name="R220" /><ref name="R58" /><ref name="R62" /><ref name="R207" />

===Goldman Sachs===
From 2000 to 2005, Patel was a managing director in Goldman Sachs' investment banking division.<ref name="R58" /><ref name="R212" /> He founded and led the bank's Strategic Group and served as managing director and head of the group.<ref name="R220" /><ref name="R58" /><ref name="R211" /><ref name="R212" /> In 2003, \'\'The Globe and Mail\'\' referred to him as Goldman Sachs\' "chief futurologist".<ref name="R220" /> He said the group\'s role was to show clients "how to leapfrog the world, not catch up".<ref name="R220" />

===Greater Pacific Capital===
In 2005, Patel left Goldman Sachs and co-founded the London-based private equity firm Greater Pacific Capital, where he serves as chief executive.<ref name="R147" /><ref name="R187" /><ref name="R211" /><ref name="R221" /> The firm has been described as established to invest in India and China; in 2013 it acquired a 20% stake in Edelweiss Capital.<ref name="R203" /> It has invested and raised funds in sectors such as education technology, electric vehicles and artificial intelligence.<ref name="R147" /><ref name="R150" /><ref name="R151" /><ref name="R153" /><ref name="R169" /><ref name="R170" /><ref name="R171" /> In 2013, Greater Pacific Capital was among the advisers to Apollo Tyres on its US$2.5 billion acquisition of Cooper Tire & Rubber Co.<ref name="R204" /> The Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC) committed US$125 million to one of the firm's funds in 2018.<ref name="R202" />

===Force for Good Initiative===
Patel founded and chairs the Force for Good Initiative, established in support of the UN Secretary-General's roadmap for sustainable development.<ref name="R187" /> The initiative has published research drawing on engagement with global financial institutions and technology companies.<ref name="R187" /><ref name="R188" /> Patel is listed as lead author on the report series ''Capital as a Force for Good'' and ''Technology as a Force for Good''.<ref name="R178" /><ref name="R179" /><ref name="R219" /><ref name="R187" /> In 2025, Force for Good published ''The World Investment Plan''; Club de Madrid described the report as proposing a US$125 trillion investment plan through 2035 and quoted Patel as the initiative's chairman.<ref name="R215" /><ref name="R219" /> A UNFCCC COP30 dialogues report listed Patel as a panelist, as chair of Force for Good; one session referenced an investment plan developed by the initiative.<ref name="R214" /> The International Institute for Sustainable Development's SDG Knowledge Hub summarized Force for Good's technology report and its relevance to the Sustainable Development Goals.<ref name="R180" />

===Institutional and advisory roles===
Patel has served as a trustee and executive director of the World Academy of Art and Science and has published in its journal ''Cadmus''.<ref name="R176" /> He serves on the advisory board of the UN Business and Human Security Initiative at the London School of Economics and Political Science.<ref name="R193" /> In 2019, he participated in the Future Capital initiative co-hosted at UN headquarters in New York by UN Trade and Development (UNCTAD), the UN Office for Partnerships and the World Academy of Art and Science.<ref name="R195" /> He was asked to define and lead its working group on the future of finance in support of the 2030 Agenda.<ref name="R195" /> A UNCTAD update in 2020 described him as the initiative's project lead and reported on progress and preliminary findings from the working group.<ref name="R196" /> Patel has also been listed as a member of the SDSN Europe Senior Working Group on the European Green Deal and the SDGs.<ref name="R198" /> He has been listed as a member of the Jane Goodall Legacy Foundation's Council for Hope.<ref name="R213" />

sections.heading: Public speaking and media
sections.wikitext: Patel has given interviews and participated in panels on geopolitics, technology, capital allocation and sustainable development.<ref name="R172" /><ref name="R222" /> He has appeared on ''SALT Talks'' and moderated a research-summit panel at the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) focused on technology, artificial intelligence and sustainability.<ref name="R172" /><ref name="R222" />

sections.heading: Ideas and contributions
sections.wikitext:
Patel's published work addresses systemic transition and systemic risk in the international order, with emphasis on the interaction of geopolitics, technology and capital allocation.

===Great-power transitions and the international order===
In 2025, Patel and co-authors argued in ''Frontiers in Political Science'' that major powers tend to pass through identifiable life-cycle phases, and they assessed implications for U.S. strategic positioning and alliance structures.<ref name="R174" />

===Capital allocation and development finance===
Writing in ''Cadmus'' in 2025, Patel and co-authors argued that progress toward the UN Sustainable Development Goals is constrained less by the absolute availability of capital than by allocation mechanisms, incentives and risk pricing.<ref name="R161" /> In Reuters commentaries, he has discussed approaches to closing development-finance gaps and to aligning investment with sustainability objectives.<ref name="R188" /><ref name="R189" />

===Climate policy pathways===
In ''Frontiers in Environmental Economics'', Patel and co-authors examined economic and governance implications of the 2023 UN Climate Change Conference (COP28). They highlighted what they described as gaps between stated commitments and implementation pathways.<ref name="R197" />

===Information-era security and "cognitive empires"===
A 2025 SSRN preprint by Patel set out the concept of "cognitive empires". It argued that algorithmic systems can shift power projection toward influence over attention and decision-making, with implications for individual agency, sovereignty and security.<ref name="R177" />

===Global turbulence frameworks===
Patel co-authored a series of ''Cadmus'' articles in 2025 proposing frameworks for understanding "global turbulence" and policy responses to interlinked crises across security, development and governance.<ref name="R176" /><ref name="R175" />

===Technology and development pathways===
Across Force for Good reports, Patel and collaborators have argued that digital technologies could materially accelerate progress toward development targets when paired with governance and investment frameworks.<ref name="R179" /><ref name="R180" /> In 2003, Patel discussed the convergence of mobile telephony and payments as an example of how consumer technology could reshape markets. He described mobile-based checkout payments and suggested partnerships between handset makers, network operators and card networks; he also proposed low-cost, pre-charged phones for markets with limited access to phone service. In the same interview, he argued that pharmaceutical business models were vulnerable to political and consumer pressure over drug prices and proposed a large R&D fund backed by governments and philanthropies to accelerate drug development and reduce costs.<ref name="R220" />

In 2023, Patel said that India's economic trajectory and geopolitical position were reinforcing each other, stating that "This will be India's century".<ref name="R221" /> He described India's digital identity and payments infrastructure as enabling large-scale financial inclusion and lowering transaction frictions across the economy. The reforms were associated with the opening of around half a billion bank accounts and about US$20 billion in deposits from new account holders.<ref name="R221" />

sections.heading: Influence and reception
sections.wikitext:
UN Trade and Development (UNCTAD) described the Future Capital initiative's working group draft report as "unprecedented" in defining activities that could make an entity or industry a "force for good".<ref name="R196" /> UNCTAD said the project could support UN work on advancing investment in the Sustainable Development Goals.<ref name="R196" /> In a response article in ''Cadmus'', Stefan Brunnhuber described Patel and co-authors' SDG-financing paper as "seminal" and "highly novel".<ref name="R184" /> Patel has also published Reuters commentaries on the SDGs and global development finance.<ref name="R188" /><ref name="R189" />

A review in ''Business Standard'' described ''The Master Strategist'' as arguing that strategic thinking can be deliberately developed as a discipline and presenting a framework for doing so.<ref name="R210" /> The book was also reviewed in the ''IMFO'' journal (Institute of Municipal Finance Officers).<ref name="R185" /> Promotional material has carried endorsement quotations attributed to Nelson Mandela, who described it as important for those seeking a more peaceful and unified world.<ref name="R181" /><ref name="R218" /> Other endorsements quoted in promotional material include statements attributed to Nandan Nilekani and Nobuyuki Idei, who characterised the book as a broad framework for strategy and personal decision-making.<ref name="R181" /><ref name="R218" /> A quotation attributed to Scott Kapnick praised the scope of its thinking on global strategic themes, while ''Director'' magazine described it as a "wake-up call" and a positive inspiration for strategists and policymakers.<ref name="R181" /><ref name="R218" /> John Paul Flintoff, writing in ''The Sunday Times'', remarked on what he called the book's "lofty" outlook.<ref name="R218" />

sections.heading: Personal life
sections.wikitext: Patel lives in London and has cited meditation and long-distance running among his interests.<ref name="R58" />

sections.heading: Selected works
sections.wikitext:
* ''Who knows wins: using information to create and sustain strategic advantage'' (Jordans, 1996).<ref name="R201" />
* ''The Master Strategist: Power, Purpose and Principle'' (Hutchinson, 2005).<ref name="R216" /><ref name="R145" /><ref name="R183" />
* "American hegemony at a critical juncture, lessons from history's great powers" (with Christian Hansmeyer, Nandan Desai and Aditya Ajit), ''Frontiers in Political Science'' (2025).<ref name="R174" />
* "Funding the Sustainable Development Goals is Not a Challenge of Sufficient Capital" (with Christian Hansmeyer, Nandan Desai and Aditya Ajit), ''Cadmus'' (2025).<ref name="R161" />
* "Sources and Solutions for Global Turbulence" (with Garry Jacobs), ''Cadmus'' (2025).<ref name="R176" />
* "Turbulent Times: A Framework for Navigating Global Crisis Through Conscious Transformation" (with Christian Hansmeyer), ''Cadmus'' (2025).<ref name="R175" />
* "The Rising Age of Cognitive Empires: Colonising the Mind" (preprint), SSRN (2025).<ref name="R177" />
* "The impact of COP28 on energy policy and the global economy" (with Christian Hansmeyer, Nandan Desai and Aditya Ajit), ''Frontiers in Environmental Economics'' (2024).<ref name="R197" />
* "Comment: How to overcome the $137 trillion shortfall to fund the Global Goals" (Reuters commentary, 2023).<ref name="R188" />
* "Comment: How to invest for impact and returns" (Reuters commentary, 2024).<ref name="R189" />

sections.heading: Further reading
sections.wikitext:
* Reguly, Eric (29 December 2003). "Undercover futurologist". ''The Globe and Mail''.<ref name="R220" />
* Nissel, Jason (29 May 2005). "Ketan Patel and Thomas Friedman: Just stop the world, so the West can get off". ''The Independent''.<ref name="R58" />
* "Greater Pacific picks up 20% in Edelweiss Cap". ''Business Standard'' (15 February 2013).<ref name="R203" />
* "India's Apollo Tyres to buy Cooper Tire for $2.5 billion". ''Hindustan Times'' (12 June 2013).<ref name="R204" />
* "Greater Pacific Capital hits first close of $300 million in $700 million India-focused fund". ''Mint'' (6 August 2018).<ref name="R147" />
* "India’s booming and that’s excellent news for Australia". ''The Sydney Morning Herald'' (13 June 2023).<ref name="R221" />
* "Force for Good Report Explores Role of Technology in Helping Reach SDGs". SDG Knowledge Hub (International Institute for Sustainable Development) (2 February 2023).<ref name="R180" />
* United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) (2019–2020). "Future Capital" initiative coverage and launch reporting.<ref name="R195" /><ref name="R196" />
* Ghosh, Nirmal (17 September 2021). "UN faces US$100t shortfall in fight against climate change, inequality". ''The Business Times''.<ref name="R144" />

Independent review of The Master Strategist (Business Standard)
Independent review of The Master Strategist (IMFO)
Invited speaker and interview subject in recorded forums (SALT, CES, WAAS, COP29 and other conferences)
Named as CEO/co-founder of Greater Pacific Capital in business press coverage (e.g., Mint; The Business Times)
Publisher pages include endorsement quotations from prominent public figures for The Master Strategist
Quoted and profiled in Australian national press on India and geopolitics (The Sydney Morning Herald, 2023)
Reuters author page and published Reuters sustainability commentaries
UNCTAD coverage of Future Capital identifying Patel as finance working group lead (2019–2020)
gaps_to_fill: Full birthdate (day-month-year) from a reliable published biographical source suitable for Wikipedia infobox use.
Additional substantial independent profiles synthesizing Patel’s career and influence beyond deal coverage and event materials.
